definition: Identify these Pulitzer Prize winning novels of the 1920s. Dallas tries to arrange a reunion between his father Newland Archer and Newland's former lover Ellen Olenska in this 1921 winner by Edith Wharton.

Identify these Pulitzer Prize winning novels of the 1920s. Sinclair Lewis rejected the 1926 Pulitzer for this novel, in which the title doctor is sent to St. Hubert to test his cure for the plague before devoting his life to research with fellow McGurk Institute colleague Terry Wickett.

Identify these Pulitzer Prize winning novels of the 1920s. One character in this novel is a former interrogator for the Inquisition who raises and coaches the singer La Perichole. After a bad infection kills his twin, Manuel lies to Abbess Madre Maria about his identity and agrees to sail with Captain Alvarado before dying in the central event of this novel. The Marquesa of Montemayor, Pepita, Uncle Pio, and Jaime are the other lives detailed in a book by the Franciscan monk Brother Juniper, who witnesses their deaths. Name this 1927 novel about the collapse of the title structure, a novel by Thornton Wilder.
term: The Bridge of San Luis Rey

definition: Answer these questions about characters who fish. In this Hemingway novella, the fisherman Santiago attempts to reel in a large marlin but it is eaten by sharks.
term: The Old Man and the Sea

definition: Answer these questions about characters who fish. This captain of the Pequod lost a leg to the title whale that he vows vengeance against in Melville's Moby Dick.

Answer these questions about characters who fish. In one novel by this author, a group of tuna fishermen crash a party in which Sanskrit poetry from Black Marigolds is read to residents of the title street of sardine factories. In addition to that novel about Mack's efforts to throw two parties for Doc, this author wrote a work in which Carlson's shooting of Candy's dog foreshadows one of the protagonists mercy-killing his rabbit-loving friend. In his most famous novel, this author wrote about the Joad family leaving the Dust Bowl in hopes of farming the title fruit. What author wrote about George and Lennie in Of Mice and Men and about the Great Depression in The Grapes of Wrath?
Identify the following short stories. The title character of this James Thurber story imagines himself doing heroic actions like facing a firing squad and flying a fighter plane against Germany.
term: ˈˈThe Secret Life of Walter Mittyˈˈ

definition: Identify the following short stories. In this O. Henry story, Della sells her hair to buy a watch chain for her husband Jim, but Jim has sold his watch to buy a comb for Della.

Identify the following short stories. At one point in this story, a character takes time to listen to the ˈˈthe beating of the dragon flies' wings, the strokes of the water spiders' legsˈˈ after splashing into some water. The protagonist of this story wonders what a sharp beating sound is though it turns out to only be his own watch. While running toward his home and his wife, the protagonist of this story feels a sharp pain on his neck. Earlier, that protagonist of this story had been tricked by a Federal scout into attempting to burn the title structure but was caught and sentenced to death. Peyton Farquhar is hanged by a group of Union soldiers in what short story by Ambrose Bierce?
term: ˈˈAn Occurrence at Owl Creek Bridgeˈˈ

definition: Name these Edgar Allan Poe short stories. The narrator of this story attempts to kill the title animal, which may be a reincarnation of his former pet Pluto, but ends up killing his wife with an axe instead.
Name these Edgar Allan Poe short stories. In this story, Montresor lures Fortunato into the catacombs, which eventually become his tomb, by promising to let Fortunato taste the title wine.

Name these Edgar Allan Poe short stories. The narrator of this story claims that the costume of the title character had ˈˈout Heroded Herod.ˈˈ This story describes musicians laughing and smiling after the chiming of a black clock every hour. One character rushes from a blue room with a dagger in pursuit of another character in a room with scarlet windows and black tapestries. Of the one thousand guests at the central event in this story, Prince Prospero is the first victim of a masked figure. Identify this story in which all of the guests at a ball mysteriously die of the title disease.
term: ˈˈThe Masque of the Red Deathˈˈ

definition: Name these American poets. This poet wrote ˈˈlet be be the finale of seemˈˈ in ˈˈThe Emperor of Ice Creamˈˈ and began another famous poem with ˈˈAmong 20 snowy mountains the only moving thing was the eye ofˈˈ the title bird.

Name these American poets. This poet wrote about ˈˈa splash quite unnoticedˈˈ in ˈˈLandscape with the Fall of Icarusˈˈ and about a narrator apologizing for eating plums that were ˈˈso sweet / so coldˈˈ in another poem.

Name these American poets. This poet described the ˈˈbreathing figures [that] learnt from thee to liveˈˈ in a poem addressed to a young painter, S.M. This poet wishes that the addressee of another poem ˈˈproceed with virtue on thy sideˈˈ and wishes that addressee ˈˈA crown, a mansion, and a throne that shine with gold unfading.ˈˈ In another poem, this author wrote that ˈˈsome view our sable race with scornful eyeˈˈ though she still claims that ˈˈTwas mercy brought me from my pagan landˈˈ about her experience being kidnapped and enslaved. Name this eighteenth century American poet of ˈˈOn Being Brought from Africa to Americaˈˈ and ˈˈTo His Excellency General Washington.ˈˈ

Answer these questions about the Fireside poets. This poet describes the ˈˈlarge and sinewy handsˈˈ of the title character in ˈˈThe Village Blacksmith.ˈˈ He also described the love triangle between Priscilla Mullins, John Alden, and Miles Standish in another poem.

Answer these questions about the Fireside poets. This poet writes that the title bird's ˈˈwings have fanned . . . the cold, thin atmosphereˈˈ in ˈˈTo a Waterfowl.ˈˈ This poet describes death as an ˈˈinnumerable caravanˈˈ in his most famous poem.

Answer these questions about the Fireside poets. The speaker of this poem claims that ˈˈmany an eye has danced to seeˈˈ this poem's subject, which was ˈˈonce red with heroes' blood.ˈˈ The speaker entreats that the title object be given ˈˈto the god of stormsˈˈ and commands ˈˈNail to the mast her holy flag.ˈˈ After this poem was published, its historical subject was preserved as a monument. Beginning ˈˈAy tear her tattered ensign downˈˈ is what poem titled for the nickname of the ship USS Constitution, by Oliver Wendell Holmes?

Name these literary families from American plays. One member of this family, Biff, stole a fountain pen from Mr. Oliver, who doesn't remember this family's patriarch Willy. What family is featured in Death of a Salesman?

Name these literary families from American plays. One member of this family, Walter, has plans to use a ten thousand dollar insurance check to open a liquor store with Willie Harris, while Lena has plans to buy a house in the white-only Clybourne Park. What family is featured in A Raisin in the Sun?

Name these literary families from American plays. One member of this family is repulsed by the sexual advances of Josie Hogan in A Moon for the Misbegotten. In another play, one member of this family blames her mental state on a lack of sleep caused by a foghorn outside her window, and that character later drags her wedding gown around the house. Dr. Hardy diagnoses another member of this family, Edmund, as having tuberculosis, which is blamed on this family's patriarch for not paying enough money for good doctors. This family includes the mentally unstable Jamie and the morphine-addicted Mary. What family is central to Eugene O'Neill's Long Day's Journey into Night?
Name these bodies of water in American literature Henry David Thoreau lived in solitude on a small cottage on this pond, where he spent only twenty-eight dollars over the course of two years.

Name these bodies of water in American literature Kate Chopin's The Awakening ends with Edna Pontellier walking into this body of water to drown herself. Earlier Edna had vacationed with her Creole husband Leonce at Grand Isle on this body of water.

Name these bodies of water in American literature Steve Baker, Magnolia Hawks, Julie Dozier, and Gaylord Ravenal are all performers on the Cotton Blossom on this body of water in Edna Ferber's Show Boat. The narrator agrees to retrieve ten thousand dollars for Karl Ritter before finding out the town the money is hidden in has been washed away in a memoir named for this body of water, in which Mr. Bixby teaches the protagonist how to work on a steamboat. On Jackson's Island, the title character of another work about this river meets Miss Watson's escaped slave Jim. Name this river that Mark Twain wrote about in Life on [this river] and Huckleberry Finn.

Identify these American cities given some references to them in literature. One character from this city has relationships with Sophie, Thea, and Stella. That novel, The Adventures of Augie March, begins ˈˈI am an American, [this city] born.ˈˈ This city is also called ˈˈHog Butcher of the Worldˈˈ in another work.

Identify these American cities given some references to them in literature. Fareek Fanon is accused of assaulting a white woman in this city in Tom Wolfe's A Man in Full. Scarlett O'Hara is living in this city when it is besieged by Union soldiers in Gone with the Wind.

Identify these American cities given some references to them in literature. A white character from this city is disturbed by the lynching of a young black man in Ralph Ellison's story ˈˈA Party Down at the Square.ˈˈ In a novel partially based on interviews with people from this city, Topsy is educated by the supposedly-kindly Augustine St. Clare. After escaping to this city from Sweet Home, Sethe's home at 124 Bluestone Road in this city is haunted by the title character. In what city is Toni Morrison's Beloved set, a city that many escaped slaves passed through after crossing from Kentucky to Ohio?

Identify these poems by Robert Frost. The title character of this poem is Silas, a laborer who has returned to work for Mary and Warren. This poem defines home as the place where ˈˈthey have to take you in.ˈˈ
term: ˈˈThe Death of the Hired Manˈˈ

definition: Identify these poems by Robert Frost. In this poem, a buzz saw cuts open the hand of a boy who does not survive the amputation surgery. This poem takes its title from a line Lady Macbeth utters after imagining Duncan's blood on her hands.

Identify these poems by Robert Frost. This poem notes how we ˈˈforthwith found salvation in surrenderˈˈ and possessed ˈˈwhat we were still unpossessed by.ˈˈ This poem's final lines describe a certain entity as ˈˈstill unstoried, artless, unenhanced.ˈˈ That entity in this poem is described as being ours in ˈˈMassachusetts, in Virginia.ˈˈ Frost changed its last line from ˈˈsuch as she would becomeˈˈ to ˈˈsuch as she will becomeˈˈ for a famous recitation of this poem. This poem begins ˈˈThe land was ours before we were the land's.ˈˈ Because of the sun's glare, Frost recited this poem instead of reading ˈˈDedicationˈˈ at a famous event. What poem did Frost recite at John F. Kennedy's inauguration?

Name these short story collections by American authors. This Bradbury collection contains the story ˈˈThere Will Come Soft Rainsˈˈ about an automated house left empty after its residents were killed in the nuclear war that leads the remainder of humanity to colonize the title place.
Name these short story collections by American authors. This story cycle by Sherwood Anderson ends with ˈˈDeparture,ˈˈ in which George Willard decides to leave the title small town.

Name these short story collections by American authors. In one story in this collection, after five nights without electricity, a wife reveals that she is buying an apartment for herself, and her husband reveals that he had held their stillborn baby in the hospital months before. In addition to ˈˈA Temporary Matter,ˈˈ in another story in this collection, a silver cocktail dress causes a seven year old to call Miranda ˈˈsexy,ˈˈ which she remembers her lover Dev whispering to her in a Mapparium. In the title story in this collection, Bobby is saved from a group of violent monkeys by the Indian tour guide Mr. Kapasi. Name this short story collection by Jhumpa Lahiri.

Name these African-American authors. This author published the autobiographical Gather Together in My Name, a sequel to a previous autobiography that detailed this author's childhood in Stamps, Arkansas with her brother Bailey.

Name these African-American authors. This author wrote about Sandy Rogers' coming of age in Kansas in Not Without Laughter but is perhaps better known for poems such as ˈˈTheme for English Bˈˈ and ˈˈI, Too, Sing America.ˈˈ

Name these African-American authors. This author published a collection of essays and speeches that examined the anthropological work of Zora Neale Hurston and the life of Flannery O'Connor. In addition to In Search of Our Mother's Gardens, this author wrote a story in which the uppity Dee visits her mother and demands to inherit a set of quilts that had been promised to her sister Maggie. That story is ˈˈEveryday Use.ˈˈ This author's most famous novel opens with the line ˈˈYou better not never tell nobody but Godˈˈ and details an affair between the jazz songstress Shug Avery and the wife of Mister, Celie. What author won the 1983 Pulitzer Prize for The Color Purple?

Name these poems. The title character of this poem, set ˈˈby the shores of Gitchee Gumee,ˈˈ is the son of the West Wind and the lover of Minnehaha. That title character of this poem is eventually converted to Christianity by missionaries to his tribe.
Name these poems. The dying narrator of this poem notices a ˈˈblue uncertain stumblingˈˈ sound of the title creature before she notes that ˈˈthe windows failed and then I could not see to see.ˈˈ
term: ˈˈI Heard a Fly Buzz When I Diedˈˈ

definition: Name these poems. This poem describes visions of ˈˈBlake-light tragedies among scholars of war.ˈˈ ˈˈSolitudes of skyscrapers and pavementsˈˈ and ˈˈpeyote pipes and drumsˈˈ are called ˈˈholyˈˈ in a footnote to this poem. The dedicatee of this poem, famous for Report from an Asylum, inspired such lines as ˈˈyou accuse your doctors of insanity and plot the Hebrew socialist revolutionˈˈ and a line in which potato salad was thrown at ˈˈCCNY lecturers on Dadaism.ˈˈ That dedicatee is Carl Solomon. What poem opens by describing the ˈˈstarving hysterical naked[ness]ˈˈ of the ˈˈbest minds of my generation,ˈˈ which the speaker claims were ˈˈdestroyed by madness,ˈˈ a Beat poem by Alan Ginsberg?
Name these notable characters from American novels. This divorcee pursues affairs with Jake Barnes, Robert Cohn, and Pedro Romero in Ernest Hemingway's The Sun Also Rises.

Name these notable characters from American novels. This character discovers the existence of a rocket with serial number 00000 that harbors the mysterious Schwarzgerat component in Thomas Pynchon's Gravity's Rainbow.

Name these notable characters from American novels. In a lecture titled ˈˈHow [this character] Was Born,ˈˈ this character's creator claimed that he was inspired by his job at the South Side Boy's Club. After his girlfriend tells him about the criminals Leopold and Loeb, this character attempts to hatch a ransom scheme for a character by framing Jan Erlone, but the scheme falls apart and ends in the murder of Bessie Mears. In the section Flight, this character is chased across some rooftops by a vigilante mob that eventually turns him in to be tried for the accidental homicide of his employer's daughter Mary Dalton. Name this protagonist of Richard Wright's Native Son.

Name these American authors of trilogies. This author wrote about the fictional Margo Dowling and Mary French and the real Sacco and Venzetti in The 42nd Parallel, 1919, and Manhattan Transfer, all part of his USA Trilogy.

Name these American authors of trilogies. This author wrote about John Grady Cole and Billy Parham working as ranchers near the demarcation between New Mexico and Mexico in All the Pretty Horses, The Crossing, and Cities of the Plain in his Border Trilogy.

Name these American authors of trilogies. In one novel by this author, the Landlord and the Merchant both send money and a son to their brother the Tiger, who uses the resources to fight neighboring warlords such as the Leopard. In another novel by this author, the protagonist meets Mary, the daughter of Dr. Wilson, during his time pursuing an agriculture degree, but cannot stand the thought of kissing her and eventually returns to his home country to fight in a revolution. A trilogy by this author that includes those two novels, Sons and A House Divided, begins with a novel that centers on the rickshaw operator Wang Lung and his wife O-Lan. What author wrote about a Chinese farming family in The House of Earth trilogy, which includes The Good Earth?
Name these American plays. In this David Mamet play, Shelley Levene and David Moss are convicted of breaking into their real estate office and stealing leads from their manager John Williamson.
Name these American plays. In this play by Tony Kushner, Louis Ironson's partner Prior discovers that he has AIDS and begins to be visited by the title heavenly creatures.

Name these American plays. One character in this play misidentifies a bouquet of snapdragons as pansies, rosemary, and violence after forcefully coming on to another character who has been made a ˈˈhouseboy.ˈˈ A story about a young man swerving his car to hit a porcupine is told twice in this play, with the second story concluding with the death of a fictional son. In a game of ˈˈGet the Guests,ˈˈ one character in this play reveals that Honey's hysterical pregnancy forced Nick into marriage. The title phrase is drunkenly sung by Martha to George in what play about an awkward party between two couples by Edward Albee?
Name these female poets. This Akron-born poet described ˈˈa deep breath and the canary in bloomˈˈ in ˈˈDusting,ˈˈ a poem in her collection Thomas and Beulah.

Name these female poets. This feminist wrote about ˈˈbright topaz denizens of a world of greenˈˈ in ˈˈAunt Jennifer's Tigersˈˈ and about an action taken after ˈˈhaving read the book of myths and loaded the cameraˈˈ in ˈˈDiving into the Wreck.ˈˈ

Name these female poets. This author wrote a poem whose title creature is ˈˈrestless,ˈˈ ˈˈunrelenting,ˈˈ and ˈˈnot freeˈˈ and whose fury is ˈˈnot on her lap where the horn rests but deep in her moonpit, growing.ˈˈ In addition to ˈˈThe Black Unicorn,ˈˈ this poet wrote an essay about abolishing patriarchy that declares ˈˈthe master's tools will never dismantle the master's house.ˈˈ This poet's struggles with her mastectomy are outlined in The Cancer Journals. Name this self-described ˈˈlesbian, mother, warrior, poet,ˈˈ a Black author who wrote Sister, Outsider and Zami: A New Spelling of My Name.

Answer the following questions about Jack London. In this London novel, the main character was formerly owned by Judge Miller and kills Spitz while part of a sled dog team. He eventually attacks a group of Yeehat natives after they kill his master John Thornton.

Answer the following questions about Jack London. In this other London novel, Grey Beaver finds Kiche and her cub, the title character who is used by Beauty Smith for dog fighting before being bought by Weedon Scott.

Answer the following questions about Jack London. In one novel by London, a man with this profession named Pat Glendon Jr. marries Maud Sangster who interviews him and helps reveal corruption within his profession. In London's story ˈˈThe Mexicanˈˈ, Felipe Rivera engages in this profession to support a revolutionary junta in Mexico. Another man with this profession, Tom King, is too poor to afford the title ˈˈPiece of Steakˈˈ before eventually quitting because of his age. Danny Ward is another London character with this profession that is contracted to engage another man in this profession in which he loses despite his fame at it. Identify this profession which was corrupted by fixed fights and includes practitioners like Muhammad Ali.
term: Boxer [accept word forms like boxing; prompt on ˈˈfighterˈˈ or equivalents]

definition: Answer these questions about American literary movements. This postmodern movement with members including Neal Cassidy and Lawrence Ferlinghetti rejected conflict and the arms race in favor of Eastern Ideals, as seen in the poem ˈˈWichita Vortex Sutra.ˈˈ

Answer these questions about American literary movements. Beat poets met in this city during the Six Gallery Reading where one poem which later faced an obscenity trial was first read. Ferlinghetti's City Lights Bookstore is located in this California city.

Answer these questions about American literary movements. This author claimed ˈˈEverything/Is Ignorant of its own emptinessˈˈ in the one hundred thirteenth section of his collection Mexico City Blues. This author included sections of his Book of Haikus in a novel in which the protagonist joins Ray Smith and Henry Morley in climbing Matterhorn Peak in California. In that novel, by this man, Ray and Japhy Ryder represent the title characters heavily influenced by Buddhism. In another novel by this author, originally written on a scroll, Carlo Marx is visited by some of his friends before Sal Paradise returns to San Francisco. Name this American author of The Dharma Bums and On the Road.

Answer these questions about the works of Edgar Allan Poe. Poe described his process of writing this poem as well as general rules for poetry in his essay ˈˈThe Philosophy of Composition.ˈˈ The speaker of this poem hears ˈˈrapping at my chamber doorˈˈ before the title creature perches itself on a ˈˈpallid bust of Pallas.ˈˈ

Answer these questions about the works of Edgar Allan Poe. In ˈˈThe Raven,ˈˈ the speaker mourns the loss of this ˈˈsainted maidenˈˈ lover. In another poem, the speaker asks for ˈˈAn anthem for the queenliest deadˈˈ referring to this character.

Answer these questions about the works of Edgar Allan Poe. In Poe's story ˈˈA Predicament,ˈˈ Signora Psyche Zenobia is decapitated by one of these objects but continues to talk as her servant Pompey runs away. In another story, a town whose name references one of these objects is obsessed with them and cabbages, before a fiddle player kills a villager operating one of them. In a third story, one of these objects causes a ˈˈbrief disconcert of the whole gay companyˈˈ before everyone continues dancing. In that story, one of these objects made of ebony signals the arrival of the Red Death at midnight. Name these large objects, whose chiming periodically interrupts guests of Prince Prospero.

Identify these African American authors. In one of this author's novels, children are named by flipping to random Bible passages, like First Corinthians. Milkman Dead searches for gold with Guitar in that novel, Song of Solomon.

Identify these African American authors. In one of this author's novels, Celie marries Mister despite his initial attraction to Nettie, Celie's sister. They both want to escape their abusive father Alphonso. Identify this author of The Color Purple.

Identify these African American authors. One work by this author suggests that racial tension would be reduced if people abandoned Christianity and its hypocrisies. That work by him describes a dinner party in which he met Elijah Muhammad. This author criticized Richard Wright for portraying Bigger Thomas as a stereotypical African American person in his essay ˈˈNotes of a Native Son.ˈˈ This author described a homosexual affair between David and the title character who is about to be guillotined in the beginning of his novel Giovanni's Room. Identify this author of Go Tell It on the Mountain.

Answer some questions about nineteenth century American poetry. This poem describes nature as one who ˈˈhas a voice of gladness, and a smile/And eloquence of beauty.ˈˈ It advises one to go not to death like ˈˈthe quarry-slave at nightˈˈ but rather to ˈˈapproach thy grave/Like one who wraps the drapery of his couch /About him.ˈˈ

Answer some questions about nineteenth century American poetry. The author of that poem, William Cullen Bryant, also wrote a poem about one of these creatures in which the speaker asks ˈˈWhither, ˈmidst falling dew ... dost thou pursue Thy solitary way?ˈˈ

Answer some questions about nineteenth century American poetry. In Bryant's poem ˈˈThe Embargo,ˈˈ the speaker asks this figure to ˈˈrestore our happy state againˈˈ and ˈˈlift our wondˈring Eagle to the sky!ˈˈ In another poem about this figure, the speaker demands the ˈˈgrace and glory of thy martial bandˈˈ after calling him ˈˈfirst in peace and honors.ˈˈ The speaker of that poem wonders ˈˈShall I to [this figure] their praise recite?ˈˈ before asking him to ˈˈProceed, great chief, with virtue on thy side.ˈˈ That poem ends by granting this figure ˈˈA crown, a mansion, and a throne that shine/With gold unfading.ˈˈ Identify this subject of a Phillis Wheatley poem, an American general during the Revolution.

Answer these questions about the winner of the 1930 Nobel Prize in Literature, Sinclair Lewis. This novel by Lewis ends with Ted revealing his secret wedding with Eunice to the title character, who has an affair with Tanis Judique, before devoting himself to help his ailing wife Myra.

Answer these questions about the winner of the 1930 Nobel Prize in Literature, Sinclair Lewis. Babbitt is set in this fictional Midwestern city, which is revealed to be the capital of Winnemac in another of his novels.

Answer these questions about the winner of the 1930 Nobel Prize in Literature, Sinclair Lewis. This novel's protagonist is employed by a terrible author who promotes campaigns including ˈˈBetter Babies Weekˈˈ and ˈˈStop the Spitter Week.ˈˈ That protagonist rivaled a member of Digamma Pi, Angus Duer. In this novel, the protagonist is hailed as a hero after saving a baby in the town of Wheatsylvania. Researchers at the McGurk institute including Max Gottlieb pressure this novel's protagonist to publish his research about a bacteriophage that could cure the plague, before he travels to St. Hubert to test it, only to have his wife die from it. Identify this Sinclair Lewis novel about the title doctor.
Name these authors of short stories. This author wrote about a young woman considering abortion in ˈˈHills Like White Elephantsˈˈ and about Harry dying of gangrene in ˈˈThe Snows of Kilimanjaro.ˈˈ

Name these authors of short stories. This author wrote about Beatrice's father making her physically poisonous to men in ˈˈRappacciniˈs Daughterˈˈ and about the reverend Hooper's title ever-present garment in ˈˈThe Minister's Black Veil.ˈˈ

Name these authors of short stories. This author wrote about a woman who writes to Don Crane about his baby being mentally disabled and other vicious letters before her roses are destroyed. In addition to that story about Adela Strangeworth, ˈˈThe Possibility of Evil,ˈˈ this author wrote about a little boy receiving the title snack from Mr. Johnson, who, after a day of good deeds, agrees to switch with his wife and be evil the next day. In a more famous story, this author wrote about Mr. Graves setting up a stool and box for a ceremony run by Mr. Summers. In that story, a paper with a black dot is drawn by Tessie Hutchinson, who must be stoned to death. Name this author of ˈˈOne Ordinary Day with Peanutsˈˈ and ˈˈThe Lottery.ˈˈ

Name these American female poets. ˈˈThe Anniadˈˈ is a mock epic poem collected in this author's book Annie Allen. Richard Wright pushed for the publication of her collection A Street in Bronzeville, and she wrote the poem ˈˈWe Real Cool.ˈˈ
Name these American female poets. This member of the Algonquin Round Table and wife of Alan Campbell quipped ˈˈMen seldom make passes at girls who wear glassesˈˈ in her poem ˈˈNews Item.ˈˈ

Name these American female poets. The speaker ˈˈcaught the quaint Italian quip she flung him from the gutterˈˈ in one of her poems where the speaker comments on ˈˈThe women squatting on the stoopsˈˈ and the ˈˈLittle dirty Latin child.ˈˈ In another of her poems, the speakers imagines herself as ˈˈA ghost in marble of a girl you knewˈˈ after wondering ˈˈI think I should have loved you presently.ˈˈ This author of ˈˈMacdougal Streetˈˈ wrote a poem whose speaker repeats the phrase ˈˈAnd all I saw from where I stood/Was three long mountains and a wood.ˈˈ That poem, ˈˈRenascence,ˈˈ is by this author, as is one in which begins ˈˈMy candle burns at both ends.ˈˈ Identify this author of the poem ˈˈFirst Fig.ˈˈ

Identify these novels set during World War II. This Norman Mailer novel set on the island of Anopopei includes ˈˈChorusˈˈ and ˈˈTime Machineˈˈ subdivisions in each of its sections. In the second section, Croft shoots a Japanese POW and Gallagher's wife dies in childbirth.

Identify these novels set during World War II. Willie Keith becomes captain of the title ship following a kamikaze attack during the Okinawa campaign in this Herman Wouk novel which won the 1951 Pulitzer Prize.

Identify these novels set during World War II. In a flashback in this novel, Katje Borgesius and Gottfried are kept as sex slaves by SS Captain Blicero, while the octopus Grigori is trained to attack Katje. Laszlo Jamf is suggested to have classically conditioned this novel's protagonist, who is surprised to see the S-Gerät component of a weapon marked with five zeroes in a section titled ˈˈUn Permˈ au Casino Hermann Goeringˈˈ. Edward Pointsman and Roger Mexico notice the similarities between the Poisson distribution and a certain reaction of the protagonist in this novel, which seemingly predict a V-2 rocket attack. Identify this novel about Tyrone Slothrop, written by Thomas Pynchon.

Answer these questions about dystopian literature. In this Sinclair Lewis novel, the New Underground opposes the regime of Buzz Windrip, President of America, who imposes his authority with the Minute Men.
Answer these questions about dystopian literature. Avis Everhard writes a manuscript detailing the rule of the Oligarchy in this Jack London novel with years measured in Brotherhood of Man.

Answer these questions about dystopian literature. In a short story by this author, John Lyle and Sister Judith join the ˈˈCabal,ˈˈ a revolutionary organization bent on overthrowing the regime of ˈˈChristian Prophetsˈˈ in America. That story, ˈˈIf This Goes On--,ˈˈ is collected in his The Past Through Tomorrow, which is part of his ˈˈFuture Historyˈˈ series of dystopian literature. In one of his novels, Nurse Gillian Boardman treats the protagonist who summarizes life as ˈˈThou art Godˈˈ after having religion explained to him and later creates the ˈˈChurch of All Worlds.ˈˈ In that novel by this author, the World Federation of Free Nations retrieves Valentine Michael Smith from Mars. Identify this science fiction author of Stranger in a Strange Land.

term: The Man in the High Castle

definition: Name these science fiction novels. At the end of the prologue to this novel, its author states what the first words of the first chapter and the last words of the last chapter will be. In this book, Edgar Denby is killed for stealing a teapot. Later, the protagonist's wife, Valencia Merble, dies of carbon monoxide poisoning. The protagonist of this novel is placed in an animal zoo with the porn star Montana Wildhack where he is watched by plunger shaped aliens named Tralfamadorians (trall-FAHM-uh-door- ee-unz). Billy Pilgrim witnesses the firebombing of Dresden in what novel written by Kurt Vonnegut?
term: Slaughterhouse-Five, or The Children's Crusade: A Duty-Dance with Death, by Kurt Vonnegut, Jr., a Fourth Generation German-American Now Living in Easy Circumstances on Cape Cod (and Smoking Too Much), Who as an American Infantry Scout Hors De Combat, as a Prisoner of War, Witnessed the Firebombing of Dresden, Germany, the Florence of the Elbe, a Long Time Ago, and Survived to Tell the Tale. This is a Novel Somewhat in the Telegraphic Schizophrenic Manner of Tales of the Planet Tralfamadore, Where The Flying Saucers Come From
